msContents.summary: Collection of cookery receipts, with a few medical and domestic receipts: by several hands. Inscribed in pencil inside the upper cover: 'J. Hodgkin. Oct. 2. 1913'.

div.p:
73730C
To Make German Puffs
No
1 German Puffs.
2 Norfolk Links
3Mock Oyster sauce,
for a boiled Turkey,
or a fowl.
4 Cracknels
5 Fry Oysters.
6 Chetenham cakes.
7 Punch for bottleing.
8 Preserve Quinces whole.
9 Puff Paste the best way.
10 Yorkshire sauce
for boiled fowles
11 Forced Eggs.
11 White Soup.
14 Snow of Apples
15 Little cakes of gingerbread 15
16 To Coller a Calves head.
17 Ragoo of Veal.
13 White Soup
12 Rich Plump cake
73730c
18 To Make a hens nest.
19 French Bread or Balls.
20 Clary wine.
21 Harts Horn Jelly.
22 Stew Cucumbers.
23 Veal Balls.
24 Stew Pigeons.
25 Ground rice Puddings.
26 Marmalade of Quinces.
27 To make custards to take
28 To make plain custards
29 To candy Angelica
30
31

Take a pint of Cream two Large spoonfulls
of flower the Yolks of four Eggs two Ounces
of Almonds beat fine: A Quarter of a
Pound of Butter Clarify'd, and when Cold
put to them the best Sugar, Sweeten to your
Taste add a Little grated Lemmon peel mix
them well together & Bake them in Butter'd
patty pans turn them out & serve them
up hott with Melted Butter with ^and sack and
Sugar Pour'd Over them

Take the tenderest parts of Piggpork, full
as much fat as lean, Shred it small as
you can, and season it to your tast with
Pepper salt Nutmeg thyme and a great
deal of sage shred Small, rub the seasoning
Well into the meat, then let your guts
be well scour'd with water & salt, so
fill them with your meat

p.head:
To make mock Oyster sauce for a Turkey or
Boil'd Fowl

div.p:
(No3) Take a quarter of pints of water and an
Anchovey a blade or two of mace a peice of
Lemmon peels five or six peper corns, and
These Ingredients to be boil'd & strain'd
and as much Butter and flower as will do for
Sauce, two spoonfulls of white Wine and
Two of Cream, keep it Stiring till it
boils to make it Smooth

(No4) Take a Gallon of fine Flower two Pound
of Butter twelve Eggs put in four of the
Whites rub in the Butter in the flower,
before you put in the Eggs, put some
Mace & Cloves beat fine, and some grat'd
Nutmeg according to your discretion.
wet them with milk, when you have made
them up; put them into a Kettle of boiling
Water, when you see them rise take them
Out, and put them into an Oven pretty
Hott but not to Scorch them

(No.5) Beat two or three Eggs with a little
grated white Bread, Nutmeg and peper;
Then dip in the Oysters and fry them
Brown in sweete Butter, scollops and
are Done the same way, but you mustake
off there Beards,

(No.6) Take three Pound & a half of fine
Flower, half a Pound of Butter, six
Spoonfulls of Yeaste, a Pinte & half of
milk, two Eggs Yolks & Whites, & a Little
Salt, about a quarter of an Hour Bakes
them, Bake them on a Fire, Cutt them out
with a Glass,

(No.7)
To Make Punch for Bottling
Take Eight quarts of Spring water five
Quarts of French of Brandy the Juice
of seven Lemmons & seven Oranges
With a small quantity of the peel of
Each & 7 pound of the Best sugar mixit all
Together & let it stand 3 month in a vesel &
then Bottle it for drinking

7
To Preserve Quinces whole in Red Jelly

(No.8) Take the fairest Scoop out the cores & pare
them, take to a pound of them 1 1/4 poundof Double
Refin'd sugar, then boil them some quince
And pippins unpar'd boil them in Water
till it be strong, take to each Pound of
Quince a pint of Liquor, Keep them close
Cover'd & let them boil till they be clear and
tender; then put them in Glasses or pots,
one in Pot which the Liquor will Jelly

(No.9) Take 1pound 3/4 of Flower rubit into pound 1/2 of
Butter, take 4 Eggs, leave out half the
Whites, beat them with as much water
as will wet the paste very limp, handle
it a little as you can, Then then roll
it round 1/2 an Inch thick, then take pound3/4 of
Butter, flower the Butter, & roll it out to the
size of your Paste, then lay it upon it
& wrap it up in a Long small peice
And roll it out to the Biggness you
would have it
8

p.head: To Make Yorkshire sauce for boil'd Fowls

div.p:
(No.10) Take the Yolks of 2 hard Eggs shred them
fine & take the Livers of the Fowles & justs
Scald or set them in Boiling water then
shred them fine & put the Eggs & Livers into
some Gravy with some Slices of Lemmon
or Juice of same Thicken & Toss them up
all together with a Little Butter, & shred
Parsly:

(No.11) Boil Eggs hard cut them in two take out
the Yolk mix it with grat'd Bread, a few
Herbs minced small a little salt peper &
Nutmeg, & a bit of Butter make it hot in
A saucepan, keep the whites in Boiling
Water, cut off the round Ends, that they
may stand well in a dish; fill the hollows
With the Yolks, miz'd as above & brown
the Top a Little with a Salamander

(No.12) Take 4 poundsof Flower dri'd 6 of Curr.ants 2 1/2 of Butter
Melted in a quarte of cream a pint & half of
Yeast, 20 Eggs half the whites, 1/2 pound of sugar 1/2 ounce
of mace an Hour & 3/4 bakes it:
9

11
To Make a White soup

(No.13) Take a knuckle of veal the Scrag end of
a neck of mutton, boil them in spring
water with a little salt, white peper, Cloves
& mace sweet Herbs, & a small onion, when
it is well boil'd strain it take the fat
Clean off, & what settles at the Bottom
when it is Cold, when it is wanted put
Cream, the Yolks of two Eggs, & as much
Vermicelli, as you like, just let it have
one boil together

(No.14) Take the pulp of 4 Apples, the whites
of two Eggs, Beat them and as the froth
Rises put it to the pulp, being Sweeten'd
beate them to gether tille its as high as you
Please on your Dish:

(No.15) Take 3pounds of Flower, 1pound of Sugar; 1pound of Butter rubb'd
in very fine, 2ounces of Ginger, well beat a Large
Nuttmeg grated, 1pound of Treacle, a 1/4 pint of
Cream, make them up Warm, bake them on
a Tin Plate, in a slack oven
10

(No.16) Take a Calves Head with the Hair on,
put it in a Kettle of water & boyle it
till the Hair comes off, then Cleave it, & take out
the Brains & all the Snivill Bones & the Eyes,
wash it Clean, tye it in a Cloth & boyl it
Tender, bone it, & season it with a little mace &
Salt, then roll it up like Brawn with tape,
and set a Weight upon it till its cold, make
a pickle of Bran & water, & when cold strain
it from the Bran & season it with salt & vineger.

p.head: To Make Ragoo of a Breaut of Veal

div.p:
(No.17) Bone your Breast of Veal, & cut a Handsome
Square peice, then cut the other part into
Small peices, then fry it Brown in Butter,
and put it in Strong Gravy, with a Little
red wine & a Little white, Anchove & Onion,
Stew all these together, fry force meat Balls
mushroom Trifles Oysters stew'd, fry'd bacon
a little Lemmon juice, and thicken this up
with Brown Butter & Garnish it Lemmon
You may put fry'd Lambstones and
Sweet breads to it and Cocks Combs

(No.18) Take 2 Calves feet & 2 Oz of Isinglass & put them
to a Gallon of water & Boil them till it come
to 3 pints then strain it & let it stand till
cold, then take away the settings, save some
of the Jelly for the Blaumange then take
the remainder & 2 a pint of white wine
the whites of six Eggs 2 Lemmons and
Sweeten it with loaf sugar & spice to
Your taste, when then Jelly is fine fill the
Bason you intend to putit on, about 3 parts
full, then let it stand till it will bare the
Eggs then boil a Handfull of Lemmon peel
Cut in Long slips, when Cold strew them
Over the Eggs, then fill the Bason with
Jelly a little warm but not to warm,
When you serve it up, put the Bason in
warm water. it comes out Better make it
the day before you use it; the Blaumange
Take 1/2 a pint of Jelly you made for your
Taste. 1/2 a pint of cream, 2 laurel leaves,
boil them in the cream, sweeten it to you
Taste with fine sugar, let it stand till
almost Cold, and a little juce of lemmon
and a Little Orange flower water, then
take 4 or 6 Eggs, break a hole in the large
End, take it all out put the shell in cold water
wash them out put your Blaumange in the
Shells, when it is Jelly'd Brake the shell off & put
them in your nest

p.head: To make French Bread or rolls

div.p:
(No.19) Break one Egg into a pound of Flower
A little ale yeast, and some salt, then
make it Light with milk & water just
warm, & set it by the fire to rise then make
it into Loaves & rolls, bake it 1/2 an
Hour, when it is cold, rasp of the out
side & then it is fitt.

(No.20) Take ten Gallons of water, put to it 25pounds
of Loaf sugar, the whites of ten Eggs,
Boil it one Hour, Suming it well, then
put it in a tub till almost cold, then
take 1/2 a Bushel of Clary in Blossom
tops & small leaves together, & put
Them into a Barrel, with six spoonfulls
of yeast, then put in the Liquor stir
it Often till it hath done working.
then stop it up Close for 3 months, till
it is Clear, you may Allow a Quarte
of water for the Scuming.

(No.21) Take 1/2pound of harts Horn, & put it into an
Earthen pan, with two Quarts of Spring
water, cover it close and sett it in the
Oven all night, then strain it into a
clean pipkin, with 1/2 pint of Renish
wine, 1/2pound of Double refin'd sugar, the
juce of 3 or 4 Lemmons, with a few
Blades of mace, the whites of 4 or 5 Eggs
well beat, let it simmer over the fire,
and mix it that it doth not curdle, then
stir it well together on the fire, run
it through a napkin and turn it up
again till it is clear

(No.22) Take 12 cucumbers pare them, and slice
them as thick as a crown peice, & put
them to drain, & then dry them in a coarse
cloth flower them and fry them brown
in Butter, pour out the fat, then put
to them some Gravy & a Little claret,
some pepper and mace & cloves, & let them
stew a little, then roll a bit of Butter in
Flower & Toss them up season with
salt, & you may Add a little mushroom
Pickle

(No.23) Take ten or twelve Little thin slices of
Veal, lay on them some force meat, and
a slip of Bacon, roll them up & tie them
with thread, put them on a bind spit rub
them over with the Yolks of Eggs, flower
them and bast them with Butter, then
Half an hour will doe them, lay them
in a dish and have ready some good
Gravy with Trifles and mushrooms,

(No.24) Season your Pigeons, with peper salt
cloves mace & some sweet Herbs, wrap
the seasoning up in a peice of Butter
and put in their Bellies, then tie up the
neck and vent, and Half roast them, then
Put them in Stewpan, with a Quart
of Good gravy, a little white wine.
a few Pickled mushrooms, a few peper
corns 3 or 4 Blades of mace, a bit of Onion
and some Pickled oysters, Lemmon peels
A Bunch of sweet herbs, let them stew
together, till they are enough, then
Thicken it up with Butter & Yolks of
Eggs, Garnish it with Lemmon

23
To Make a Ground rice Pudding

(N.25) Take six ounces of Ground rice, to a Quart
of milk, Stir it all together, then set it on
a clean fire, stiring it all the time it Boils,
Then take it off, and put to it 1/2 pound of fresh
Butter in an Earthen pan, stiring it together
And when cold, put to it seven Eggs with 3
whites beating them all together, with
Half a Grated nutmeg, 6 ounces of sugar
a Little Salt one Ounce of Orange
chips, butter your dish, and bake it an
Hour, and when out of the Oven put a Gill
of sackover it

(N.26) Let your quinces be full ripe, then wipe
them, & pare them, & Quarter them, then
take out the core and seeds, & boil the
Pareings & seeds in Spring water, strain
the Liquor, & weigh your Quinces, with
the same weight of dry 6d Sugar, boil
the Quinces, in that Liquor, & when
Tender, mash them, & then put your sugar
to the Quinces, & boil it till it Looks
red & smooth, Keeping it stired all
The time it Boils
16

(No.27) Take one pint of cream boil'd with mace
& Cinnamon, when cold take 4 Eggs, two
whites, a Little rose & Orange flower
water, & sack nutmeg & sugar, to your
Tast mix all these together, & bake them
in China Cups,

(No.28) Take 1 Quart of new milk, sweeten it to
Tast, grate in a Little nutmeg 8 Eggs
with 4 whites beat them well together
and stir them in the milk, & bake
them in Cups or a Deep China dish,
or you may have ready a Kettle of boiling
water, but it must not boil, Take care
the water does not get into the Cups.

Take Angelica & put it into water, & sett it
on the fire to Scald till it will peel, & when
you have Peel'd it, put to it fresh water
Scalding hott, then cover it clove& past
it up that none of the stem comes out, &
let it scald 3 or 4 Hours, then uncover
it & see if it be green & tender, & if not
cover it again till it is tender, then take
the weight of it in double refine sugar, & strew
some in the pan you candy it in, then lay
your Angelica, & strew more sugar [?]

27
18
To Make Jam of Apricocks

(No.30) Take Apricocks & pare them, cut them
in peices & to every Pound of them, take
3/4 poundpound of double refine Sugar, take half the
Sugar & the whole Quantity of Apricocks
& boil them as fast as you can, do not stir
them with a spoon but keep them shaking
till they are almost enough, then put in
the rest of the sugar, & give it one boil
or two and so let it cool, then put it off the
fire, you may try if it will Jelly

(No.31) Take fruit or greens, & strew them with fine
Salt, that they may be well salted, shake
them well every day, then drain the water
from them, do this for 3 days throwing a
Handfull of fresh salt every day, after
You have well drained them, then lay
them separate in the sun till they are quite
Dry, the put some of the best vinegar to them,
some mace cloves peper, beat mustard seed
and Powder of Tumerick & mace with vinegar
into a pulp, which must be mix'd with
the Other Ingredients, some cloves of Garlick
skin'd & long peper, as to the Ingredients
you must govern yourself by the Quantity
of fruit you use, Colly Flower looks pretty
this way but for Goodness the whitete cabbage is preferd

Gather your walnuts the Latter end of June
or the beginning of July, pare of the Green
very clean & prick them full of Holes, & put
them in cold water for 5 or 6 days Hours, then
put them into Boiling water, & let them
Boil, then change them into more boiling
water, & let them boil, then put them into
fresh boiling water, & let them boil a little
while, then take their weight of Double refine
Sugar, & put to it 1 1/2 pint of water, & boil them
a Little, then stick a clove in each, & put them
in the syrup, boil them till they are half
Enough, & set them by till next day, then
put through each of them a peice of cittron
or candy'd Orange peel, then take musk &
Amber grese according to the Quantity of
Nutts, tie them in a peice of fine Leather, &
put them in the syrup, then boil them till
they are enough, & keep them for your uses

Gather your nuts, as above pare of the rind
till they are white, throw them as you do
them into water & salt, Changing them 2 or 3
times, then have ready some boiling
water & milk, then put in the nuts let them
boil till they are tender, lay them on a cloth
till they are cold, then make a Pickle of white wine
& white wine Vinegar more wine then Vinigar, some cloves
Mace & whole peper, boil it well, & let it stand
till cold put them in pots or Glasses pouring the
Pickel on them, Prick holes in them
before you put them in salt & water
you may eat them in a week
19

Take a Gallon of New milk & warm it,
and put in it a Cupful of rennet, you must set
the hight before a Bit of Rennet bagg,
as bigg as a Crown peice in a Cupful of
water, & the next day put the water to
your new warm milk, & when the Curd is Come,
put it in a Cheese Cloth and wave it back
and forwards till the whey is out of it,
Then take the same weight of new Butter
as your Curd, and press it through a seive
Together, & then put you sugar, with
Eight Eggs, but 4 whites well beat, with
Spice and Currants, into puff past.
And Bake them in pans, the sugar & spice
must be to your tast, the Spice must be
mace & nutmeg, the Currants plumpt up

(No.34)
(35)
To Make force meat Balls

Take as much Veal as beef suet, some
peices of stale Bread, beat them all in a
Marble mortar, some sweet herbs,
Chopt & put it in the mortar, with Nutmeg
Mace peper and a Little salt, all beat
together, the Yolk of an Egg & a Little milk
And make them in Balls, & fry them,

Take a pack of mushrooms, wash them & wipe
them clean with a flanel, & cut out the worms.
and put them in a Broad earthen pan with
20 Cloves, & 8 Blades of mace, & as much beaten
peper as will lie on half a crown, a Handful
of salt, 3 small Onions, a peice of Butter the
size of an Egg, & 1/4 a pint of Vinegar, let them
Stew over the fire till the Liquor is wasted.
then put them into the Oven after the bread
is out, & when dry pound them to powder
with the spice, it must be kept dry in a pot, or Glass

Take 8 Eggs, beat them with a Little of the best
Brandyy, & 4 Large spoonfulls of the finest
Flower, put in a Little Nutmeg, a Little salt,
and 1/2 poundof Butter melted in a pint of Cream,
and when its almost Cold, mix it altogether
with 2 Ounces of fine sugar fry them in a
Dry pan, without fat,& let the pan be hot
when you begin, & fry them only on one
side strew fine sugar between each pancake
as you put them in the dish, & when they are
all fry'd turn them upside Down in an
other dish, that the brown side may be
Upwards & strew over them some fine sugar

Take 1/2 pound of rea raisins stone them, 1 pound of
Beef suet & chop them all fine together,
4 spoonfulls of flower, 4 spoonfulls of sugar a little
Salt 6 Eggs 3 whites beat them well
This Quantity will require 3 hours
Boiling tie the pudding Close & hard the
Sauce is Butter melted with sack & sugar

Take 1/2 pound of Blanch'd allmonds beat small
with rose water, 1/2 pound of Loaf sugar beat
fine, 3/4 pound of Butter melted & almost cold
Again, & Yolks of Eggs, well beaten the
Peel of a Large sivil Orange, boil'd till
it's very tender & the Bitter almost out.
then beat it well in a Mortar, then mix all
These together & beat it well then put it
in a Crust

Take a Quart of flower, A quarter of a pound
of Butter, 1/4 pound of Sugar, one Egg, & 2 Ozs of
Carrawayseeds, mix it with water, & roll
them very thin, & bake them quick

Take 24 good sivill Oranges, pare them
thin, put the peel asoak in a Quart of the
Best Brandy & 1 quart of sack or mountain
wine, let them steep 24 Hours, then put
to it 1 Quart more of Brandy & two Quarts
more of wine, putt them into a Cold still
and draw it off with a slow fire, in to
Dry Bottles, put into the bottles a Little
Double refine sugar to drop on, when
it is all run off that is good, let it stand
to be Cold & mix it together, make it as
sweet as you like & Bottle it up for use
the still must past round it, & a whet wet Cloth
on the top to keep in the Spirit

Take the Crumbs of a penny Loaf or two
French rolls, soak it over Night in new
warm milk about 50 Jordan Almonds
Blanch'd & beat with rose water put them
to the Bread, a Little Cream, a spoonful of
Sack, sugar & Nutmeg, salt & grated
Lemmon peel, 3 Eggs, beat it well
together either Bake, it or Boil it

Take the peel of two sivil Oranges, boil them
in 3 quarters water till tender then pound
them in a Marble Mortar till they are very
fine, take 1/2 pound of Butter, 1/2 pound of sugar, 10 Eggs
7 whites 2 maple Bisketts grated, squeeze
the Juice of 2 Oranges in it mix it fine
Together, put a past at the Bottom of your
dish & a thin past over it, 1 Hour Bake it,

Take 1 pound of Potatos & boil them, then beat them
in a Marble Mortar very fine, then take 1/2 pound
of fresh Butter, not melted & work the potatoes
with your Hands, with 1/2 pound of Loaf Sugar
finely beaten, put all these together, then
take six new Eggs, beat together a grated
Nutmeg, 1 Glass of sack, 1 1/2 oz of Cittron, 1 Oz
of candy'd Orange peel, with Past at the Bottom
and round the rim of the dish

To every Gallon of water put a pint of Honey
& 1/2 pound of Loaf sugar, stir in the whites of Eggs.
Beat to a froth, & boil it as long as any scum
arises, when its Cold work it with yeast & to
every Gallon put the Juice & peel of a Large
Lemmon stop it up when it has done working &
Bottle it in 10 days

25
(No.46)
Asparagus forced in French rolls
Take 3 French rolls, take out the crumb by
first Cutting a peice of the top Crust off
but be careful that the Crust fits the place
Again, fry the rolls Brown in fresh Butter,
then take a pint of Cream, the Yolks of six
Eggs well beat, a Little salt & nutmeg, stir
them well together over a slow fire, till it
begins grows thick, then have ready an
Hundred of small Grass, boiled, & put into the
Cream, fill the Loaves with them, before
you fry the rolls, make holes thick in the
top Crust, & stick the Grass in, that it may
Apear to be growing, it makes a pretty side
dish for a second Course,

Take the walnuts when they are fit for pickling
pound them in a Mortar, strain the Juice
through a flanel bagg, put to every quart
of Juice, a pint of Vinegar, let it stand, 4 days
then Boil it over a slow fire, to half the
Quantity, scum it a Little, put in some
Shallots, some spice & the peel of 3 sivil
Oranges par'd thin, then let it stand 3
weeks or Months Cover'd Close then boil
it & bottle it for use,
you may put in Anchove, & salt if you Please

Slit your Mellons down the sides, & take out all
the seeds, & boil them in water, till tender but
not soft then pare them very thin, & put
them in Scalding water with a bit of Clear
Alum the size of a Nutmeg, Cover them Close
in the preserving pan, until they are
Green, let them doe very slow, then take
them up, & to every pound of them take
3/4 pound of the finest sugar, & A pint of water,
Boil it and scum it, then put in your
Mellons and let them boil softly a 1/4 of
an Hour, then take them of the fire, & put
them in a Glass, & keep them Close for 2
Days then put that syrup away, and
take 1 pint of water, & 1 1/4 pound of sugar, and
when the syrup boils, put them, & boil them
with as much Ginger as you Please
till they are Green & Clear, then put in
the Juice of 3 Lemmons & let them boil some
time after the Juice is in, put them up in
Glasses they will keep two Years, doe
them from the size of a French walnut
to the size of an Orange.

Take to 50 Peaches, or Apricoks, 3 pounds 1/2 of fine
Sugar, & make into a thin syrup, then take
the fruit, & prick them in holes with a large
Needle, then put them in the syrup turning
them with a Bunch of feathers, be sure they
Are all Cover'd, let them Scald for near an
Hour but not boil, take them off the fire, &
put them one by one, into a large Earthen
Pan flat, & pour the syrup over them, let them
Boil Gently about a 1/4 of an Hour, then take
them out with Care, into pans that have
been rinsed with Brandy, then put as much
Brandy as syrup, till they are well Cover'd, let
the syrup be Lukewarm when you put it
to them, when Cold Close them with fine
Paper & Bladder, they never will be all Cover'd
at one time, so you must take them out, as
they Look Clear

Take 1 pound of Flower dry it well, then rub in
it 1/2 poundof Butter, 1/2 poundof dry 6pound Sugar, with the
Peel of Lemons Grated fine, half an ounce
of Corinander seed beat fine & sifted, Mix
these together, & wet it with the Yolks of
2 Eggs, & 2 spoonfuls of rose water,
Make them it Little Cakes & bake them
on Fire,

28
( No.51)
To Salt Beef like Dutch Beef
Take about 2 Stone of the leanside of a
Buttock of Beef, rub it all over with 1 pound of brown
sugar, then lay it Close in an Earthen pan
fitt for it & let it lie for 2 days, then take it
Out & pour the Liquor from it, then take
1 Oz of salt petre beat fine & 2 Handfuls of
Salt, & rub it over it very well, let it lie 2 days
More, then rub it over with a Handful of bay
Salt beat fine, then let it lye 4 or 5 days
more turning it every day, then wipe it dry
and hang it up to Smoak,

Take a good buttock of Beef, cut it in peices and
season it with savory Spice, 1 Oz of salt petre,
1/2 a pint of Claret, then haveing 3 or 4 pound
of Beef suet lay it between every laying of
Beef, tie a paper over it & let it lie all night,
then bake it with household bread, then take it
Out & dry it in a Cloth, cut it a Cross the grain
very Close, & rub it in your hands like flower, if
it's not season'd enough season it more,
then pour to it the fatt, Clear from the gravy,
& mix it together, then put it Close in pots
Set it in the Oven to settle Close, when
it is Cold cover it with Clarified butter,

p.head: To Make the Duke of horfolks Punch

div.p:
Take 1 Gallon of Brandy, & put the pareings very
thin par'd of six sivil Oranges & six Lemons, & steep them 3 days in the Brady, then take
1 1/2 Gallon of water, & 3 pound 1/2 of fine sugar, boil the
Water & sugar, 7 Minutes Clarify it with 16
Whites of Eggs beat to a froth, when you have
Strain'd off the Eggs, & scum'd it well, let the
Liquar stand to be Cold, then put the Juice
of Lemons & Oranges to your tast, but more
Orange than Lemon, & as well refined as you
can make it, then strain the Brandy from the
Peels & mix them together, put it in a Vessel
& let it stand six weeks, then Bottle it off,

Take 2 Quarts of Gooseberries, put to them
as much water as will cover them, then
Scald them, & run them through a sieve
with a spoon, to a quart of the pulp put 6 Eggs
well beat, sweeten it to your tast, & when it is
Hot again put in 1 Oz of Butter, keep it stiring
all the time over a slow fire, till it grows thick
& Just simers, when almost Cold put in
Basons or Glasses

Bone a breast of pork season it with savory
Spice & a great Quantity of thyme sage &
parsley, roll it in a hard Collar in a Cloth
& tie it Close, & boil it, when it is Cold
keepin it in Souceing Liquar,

Cut him through the Gills, & wash him Clean
then take thyme, savory, sweet marjoram,
Green Onions, or a Slice or two of the white, the
Liver of the fish 2 Anchovye 1/2 a Nutmeg grated
A 1/4 pound of Beef suet shred, a Little Mace beat, & the
Crumb of a peny Loaf grated, mix all these
Together, & work them into a paste & wet them
with 2 or 3 spoonfuls of cream, & the Yolks of
3 Eggs, then take a quart of Oysters scald
them & put them into your pudding & work it
Together with a Little butter, so fill the belly
of your pike, & spit him through the Gills &
Bind his body to the spit with Tape, then
Flower & baste him very Often, an Hour
will roast him, if you see him Crack take
an Egg & beat it, & dress him all over with a
feather & a Little of the Oyster Liquor, &
your Butter with it, & serve it up, Garnish
with horse Raddish sliced Lemon &
scrap'd parsly; it is as good Baked with his
tail in his Mouth

Bone your feet, & shred them small, with as
Much Beef suet as meat, put in a Glass of good
sack, a Lemon sliced, & season with cloves,
Mace, Cinnamon, & salt, 1/2 poundof currants a 1/4 pound
of sugar, & lay Candyed Orange Peel, and
Cittron, Slic'd on the top,

Take a pint of Boiled Cream, put into it a little
Nutmeg & mace, then take the Crumb of two
French rolls, & put them into the boil'd Cream,
then take the Yolks of six Eggs, & about 20
Almonds beat small & 1/2 pound of Marrow, mingle
all these well together & season it with a
Little sugar & salt, & send it to the Oven,

p.head: To Make Almond Puddings in skins

div.p:
Take 1 pound of Almonds blanched, beating them
very fine, puting often a Little Milk to keep
them from Oiling then but to them 1 pound of grat'd
Bread, 1 pound of Marrow & suet shred fine 1 pound of
fine Sugar, & 12 Eggs, six of the the whites, then
Boil 1 Quart of Cream, & when it has stand
is Just Lukewarm, put it to the rest
with salt, Nutmeg, & mace, to your tast, &
so fill your skins.

Take a pint of cream, 7 Eggs beat, with a
Little sack, & sugar, one Spoonful of flower,
and a Little salt, then butter a Wooden dish,
& strain it into it, & Butter a Cloth & tie it
fast upon it, and boil it an Hour, melt
Butter to put over it, with sack & sugar,

p.head: To Salt a Leg of Pork

div.p:
Let it lie a Month in Salt, and salt petre, then
stuff it with Parsly, sorrel, & Young Sprouts,
all pickt from the Stalks & wash'd, &
Chopt fine then Stuff it in the Leg of pork,
& tie it up in a Cloth, & boil it till it is Tender
then take it out of the Pot & shin it, & strew
on the top beat piper, & when Cold Cut it ,
You must stuff it in the Bottom, up the Leg of
Pork, as you do not break the skin

Take a Large Tongue, & salt it with bay salt
and Common salt mixed together & beat with
the salt, some brown Sugar rub your tongue
Well with these & let it Lie, a fortnight,
Weting & turning it often, then beat some
Mace, Cloves, Nutmeg, & Peper, & rub it, &
put it into a pott with as much butter &
Water as will Cover it, then put it into an
Oven & bake it about 3 hours, & when it
Comes out peel it, & put it into a pot & and
More Butter to that it was baked in, which
Must be taken from the water, & Clarify;d Butter
Poun'd on it

Pickle your Tongue, then boil it tender
Blanch it, & roast it about 1/2 an Hour sticking
it with Cloves, your sauce may be Gravy or
Claret sauce; sift some raspings of Bread,
And Garnish with that and Lemon,

Take a Gallon of new Milk, set it with a spoonful
& a Half of rinnet, let the milk be Blood warm, &
when it Comes, let the Curd Drain through a
Coarse Cloth till it is well Whey'd, now & then
Gently breaking the Curd with your fingers, but
not wringing it, for that will spoil it then rub in
to the Curd 1/2 pound of butter, & 1/2 pound of sugar, some Nutmeg
Grated, 4 Naple Bisketts grated, put in the
Yolks of 8 Eggs, but 2 whites, 2 Ozs of Blanched
Almonds finely Beaten, with 3 or 4 spoonfuls
of rose, or Orange flower Water, if you add
Sack it will be Better, then take 3/4 poundof Currants
well Clean'd, put them into your Curd, & mix
them all well together with a Little salt,

Take 4 poundof fine Flower, 1 pound1/2 of Sugar, 3 pound of
Butter, & 3 Eggs, work all these together
into a paste, & make it into thin Cakes.
Which must be Bake'd in a quick Oven on
Butter'd papers,

Take 2 Gallons of Flower well dry'd, 5 pounds of Treacle
1/2 pound of Butter, 1/2 pound of Orange & Lemon peel, shred
Small & strew'd into the flower, 2 Ozs of beaten
Ginger 1 Oz of Carraway & Coriander seed, boil
the Treacle & Butter together, & Pour it in to
the flower, & mix it altogether, & bake it on
Tin plates in what form you please,

Take a quart of Flower, 1 poundof Butter, 3/4 pound of
Carraway Comfits, six Eggs, but 2 whites, six
spoonfuls of Cream, & 6 Spoonfuls of Yeast,
beat the Cream, Eggs, & Yeast, together, then
Stir it into the flower, with the Butter first
Melted, shake it altogether, & set it befor the
fire a quarter of an Hour, that it may rise
then shake in the Comfits, & make it into
Little round Cakes & Butter the Papers you
put them on

Take a French roll, & put it into slices,
soak them in sack, then dip them in
Yolks of eggs, & fry them, and serve them
up with butter, & sack, & sugar,

Take a quart of Cream put it on the fire
with a Blade of mace, some sliced Nutmeg,
& a little Cinnamon, then take the Yolks of
ten Eggs, & beat them well with sugar to your
Tast, keep a Little Cream to beat up with
Your Eggs, when the Cream & spices have
Boiled a little while, then pour some of the
Cream Gently into the Yolks of the Eggs,
Stirring it all the time then pour it all
together, & keep the sauce pan over the fire
till it thickens, then strain it through a
hair seive & put in a Glass of Brandy
then put it in to your Cups,

Take your white Grapes when they are full
ripe, & stone & pill them, then take there weight
in Sugar, & wet your sugar with water, and
When you have Boil'd it to a pretty thick
Syrup, then put in the Grapes to it, & let
them Boil a pretty pase, & so Continue
them keep them Clean scum'd, till it begins
to Jelly, then take out your Grapes & if the
Syrup be not thick enough, boil a little
More, by it self, & when it is Cold, put the
Grapes in Glasses, with the Syrup.

Take 2 quarts of new Milk, 8 Eggs, 4 whites,
beat up with a Little rose water, a Nutmeg
Grated, a 1/4 pound of sugar, Cut a penny Loaf in
Very thin Slices, & pour milk & Eggs,
over it, put in a little bit of Butter, on the
top, Bake it in a slow oven, half an Hour

Baste them at first, with salt, & water warm
And towards the last, baste them with butter
and Catch what drops from them, & Draw
your Butter in it, with Nutmeg scraped
for the sauce, A Little drawn butter will
be Enough

p.del:
To Make Oyster Loaves
Fry the French

div.p:
Two Gallons of water, to one Gallon of Juice
3 pound of Sugar to a Gallon, strain it
put it in a cask, & when you think it
has worked Enough, put in a Quart of
Brandy to Seven Gallons if you make
but a small cask rather less sugar will do

To a Quart of Reetifyd Spirits of wine
put half an ounce of oil of Lavender,
and six penny worth of Ambergrease
you must disolve the Ambergrease by
rubbing it in the morter with a little of
the Oyl let it stand five or six days
shaking it well four or five times a Day,
then Philter it off; given me by Robert Pratt esquire

Take Your Feet & Ears out of the pickle they
are soused in or boil them till they are tender
then cut them in to little long thin bits,
about 2 Inches long & about a Quarter of an Inch
thick put them in to Your Stewpan, with
half a Pint of good Gravy, a Glass of white Wine
a good deal of mustard a good peice of Butter
Rolled in Flour a little Pepper & salt
stir all together till it is a fine thickness
then Dish it up

4 Pound & a half of Currents, 3 pound of Flour
2 pound of Butter 1 ounce of Sweet Spice
Three quarter of a pound of Sugar half a pin
of good Yeast wet it with warm Milk
Melt yout Butter in the Milk:
3 Hours Bake it

When your Tongue is tender, blanch it & Cut
it into thin Slices, pour Strong Gravy
over them, let them stew on the fire, thicken
the Liquor, with the Yolk of an Egg, and put
in 1/2 a Pint of Oysters,

p.head: To Roast a Neck of Veal

div.p:
Lard it on the out side with Bacon, then roast
it. & serve it up with a good Gravy, mix'd
with a little Butter melted, forced meat
Balls, & Sliceds of Broil'd Bacon round the
Dish, Garnish with Lemon,

Cut them into Quarters, take the seeds out,
take an Onion & a peice of fresh Butter, and
keep you pan Stiring till it is Brown
then put in your Cucumbers, cut in Slices &
Keep them shaking, & when Brown enough
take them out, & pour of all the fat, then pour
on your Gravy, with salt, peper, & Anchovys
thicken it with a Little Butter & flower,

Take the meat out of your Crabs, & put it in
a well Tin'd Saucepan, with a Little white
wine, some nutmeg, & veal Gravy, and
a peice of Butter, make the meat very Hot,
With some fine Grated bread, then fill the
Shells, & Brown it with a red hot Iron, you
May Add a Little Salt.

Take the Juice of 2 sivil Oranges, with a
Little of the peel Grated very fine, & put
as much Sugar to it as will make it sweet
give it a boil up, & strain it, & have
Ready 1/2 a pint of cream boil'd, with a
Little Nutmeg, mace, & Cinnamon, & the
whites of 3 New Eggs, beat them all together
And Serve it in What you please,

p.head: To Make a Fricasee of Mushrooms

div.p:
Peel your Mushrooms, then Quarter them, &
put them over the fire, in a Saucepan & let
them Stew, till all the Black water is Come
from them, then Pour it away, & take a peice
of Freash Butter, an Onion, Nutmeg, Cloves, & a
Blade of mace, a Little white wine, a Little parsly,
Thyme, & savory, with some Salt, shred your
herbs fine, & let them Stew 1/2 an Hour then
take a the a little Juice of Lemon,& the Yolk of an Egg,
& beat them together to thicken your fricasee
So serve it up

Cut your tripe into small slips, flouer it well
and put some beef Driping into a pan, & fry
it Crisp, then drain it well, from the fat, and
Clean your pan, then take some Butter and
flower, & make it of a pale Brown, then
put a Little good Gravy to it ,& the tripe,
And Toss it up together

p.head: To make a Fricasee of sweet Breads

div.p:
Half roast 3 Large sweet Breads, cut them
into Square peices, boil some roast beef
Gravy, with half a Nutmeg, some whole peper
a Shalot or two, & a Little salt, then strain it
And put your sweet herbs, to it, & stew them
till they are enough, put in a peice of Butter
Wrap'd in flower, & a Spoonful of Boil'd
Oyster Liquar Garnish with Lemon

p.head: To Dress a Knuckle of Veal with rice

div.p:
Take a Knuckle of Veal, cut of the Gristles, &
put them in a large, saucepan with a 1/4 poundof rice
An Onion or two Sliced, a Little mace, & salt,
put in what Water you think proper to
Make your Liquor strong & good, let it
boil very Slowly, & as it wastes put in a
Little more warm water, & let the Rice and
Gristles be boil'd Quite down, let the thick
part of the Veal be boil'd as a Knuckle of Veal
Generaly is, Serve it up, on the rice & Gristles

Season with peper, salt, mace, & nutmeg, &
And put them into an Earthen pan Just Cover'd
With water & bake them, then take them
from the Water, & when Cold, put them in a
Pan again, and pour Clarify'd Butter
over them

Take two Claves feet, & split them & take
out the Large Bones, put to them 3 pints of
river Water, a Slice of Nutmeg, a blade of
Mace, a race of Ginger, & a Little Orange and
Lemon peel Cut very thin, put it over a
slow fire, & let it boil Gently, till it comes
to a Strong Jelly, taking off the scum, then
Strain it off, & let it stand till it is Cold, then
take off the settlement, & and to it 1/2 a pint of
Milk, put it over a slow fire, & take the Yolks
of 8 Eggs & beat them well together, with a
Little Cold Milk, & when your Jelly is lukewarm
put them into it, & keep it stiring till the Eggs
are sett, then run it through a sieve & put it into
Cups you must sweeten it to your tast,

Boil 1/2 poundof Rice tender in water & milk,
then put to it 2 quarts of strong broth,
herbs, Balls, & french roll, Cut in dice & all
fry'd, season it & put in forc'd Chicken in
the Middle

Take the Yolks of 3 hard Eggs, 1 poundof
Butter, a little fine sugar a Spoonful
of Orange flower Water, & work it
Through a Seive,

41
(No.88) T
o Pickle Portugal Onions

Peel your Onions, & Cut out of the Bottom a
Small round peice, & scoop out the Insides, but
Not to thin, then put them in Salt & water three
Days, Changing it twice a day, then drain them
and stuff them, first put in flower of Mustard
Seed, then some Ginger Cut small, & a little mace
and Shalot cut small, then some more Mustard,
and fill them up with scraped Horse Radish,
then put on the Bottom Peice, & tie them down
Close, then make a Strong Pickle of White wine
Vinegar, mace, ginger, Cloves, Nutmeg, slic'd
Horse Radish, & a great deal of salt, then put in
the Mango's & let them boil up two, or three times,
but dont let them boil to Much, for then they
will lose there firmness & wont keep, then
Put them with there Pickle in a Jarr & Cover
them down close, & the next Morning boil your
Pickle up again, & pour it over them.

Take an Anchove, wash it Clean, put to it a
Glass of red wine, a little strong broth or Gravy
gravy, some Nutmeg 1 Shalot sliced & the
Juice of a sivil Orange Stew these together a
Little & pour it to the Gravy that runs from the
Meat

To every quart of Damsons, Allow 1 pound of sugar
put you Damsons in an Earthen pot Cover
them Close at the top, set it in a pan of water,
as you do Currant Jelly, & when they are stew'd
Enough, put them in Your Preserving pan, &
then the Sugar to them, & Boil them till they
Come to a Jelly together, to have them smooth,
You must before you put the Sugar to them, rub
them through a Hair seive, till you have got
all the pulp from the Stones & skins, & so boil
it till it's thick enough, to put into flat pans
if you Dont put in flat pans, it will not Cut smooth

Take your Green Coddlings & put them in a
Bell Mettal Shellet, with a Little salt, then Cover
them Close in the water & salt with two or three
Cabbage Leaves that no Stem Comes out, and
put on them the Lid of the Skellet, let them scald Gently
And when they will Just peel, pull of the Skin &
throw them in the same Liquor with the Cabbage
Leaves, as before till they are tender, only
Keep the water Scalding Hot all the time they
are doing

When the Mackerel are wash'd & drest the heads
And tails cut off, then cut off an Inch below the Fins
then boil them with a little salt & Handful of
Fennel till the fish Leaves the Bone then drain
it well from the water, & when it is near Cold,
Split them down the Middle & take out all the bones
and Season them with peper & salt, a double
Quantity of Pepper to your salt, Season them
Pretty high & lay them even & Close in an
Earthen pan not so full but there may be
room enough, for Butter to Cover them,
which must be very good, & Melted over a
Slow fire, then let the Dross settle at the
Bottom, & pour of the Clear Softly on Your
Macherel, till the fish is Cover'd, the Oven must
be heated as for Brown Bread & a pott that
Holds 12 may stand in 2 Hours, then take them
out as hot as you Can, & put them in the pot you
Intend to keep them in, & press them down as
Clos as Possible, when cold Cover them Over with
the Butter they was Bake'd in, they will keep a
Year if once in 3 or 4 Months if you scrape of
about a straws Breadth of the Butter & put them
in the Oven, to be through hot & fill them up again

Boil 1 quart of Cream or Milk, with a little Cinnamon
a Nutmeg Quarter'd & some mace, when Cold mix
it with the Yolks of 20 Eggs & 10 whites strain it then
then put to it 4 Biskits 1/2 pound of Butter a pint of spinage
Juice & a little Tansey, sack & orange flower water

p.note:
Sugar & salt then gather it to a
body oven the fire & pour it
into your dish being well
Butter'd when it is baked turn it on
a pye plate squeeze on it and
orange grate on Sugar & Garnish

div.p:
To 3 pounds of Grapes when pick'd put 1/2 pounds of sixpenny
Sugar, and one quart of water, stamp the Grapes,
and Strain the Juice from them, then put the husks
in to the water, & let them stand 24 Hours then
Strain them of as dry as you Can, put that
Liquor to the Juice of the Grapes, you must put
in some of your sugar to the Juice of the Grapes,
When they are first Strained off, & the remaindor
when the Whole is mix'd you must let Stand one
Year in Your Vessel, & then Bottle it off,

Take 3 pounds of Cherrys, bruise them with your
finger, put a quart of water, to them let them
Stand 24 Hours, to every quart of water
put a pound of sugar, Drain your Liquor
through a seive, then put the sugar in, let it
Stand 24 Hours then take off the scum, turn
it up but not put the Bung in, for it will work
some days let it Stand 1 Month before you draw it off
stir the fruit well in the water

Take the plumbs when they are Just begining
to ripen, pare them very thin, & to 1 pound of Plumb
put poundsof fine sugar & a spoonful of water to a
Plumb, boil the water & some of Sugar & pour
it on the Plumbs, & Cover them Down a Little
While, then boil them till they are Clear & green,
Strewing in the rest of the Sugar, & keeping them
Covered at first.

Take the Largest & fairest Heads of Celery,
cut of the green Part, & boil the whole heads in a
Good Quantity of water & Salt, till Tender,
then have ready, a Little white Gravy, made
of any Lean meat, with a Little mace whole
Pepper & Lemon Peel Boil'd in it, Strain
it, then half the Quantity of Cream with a
Little Parsly, boil'd & Chopt in it, a Yolk of
an Egg beat, & a bit of Butter flower'd the size
of a Walnut, mix it all well together, with
with a Little Salt & the Juice of half a
Small Lemon, then pour it over your Celery
when Ready to send in

Take 4 Quarts of new Milk & 2 of Cream
put Rennet to it, when it Comes Cut up the
Cheese as thin as you Can with a
Seiming Dish, & lay it in the fatt till it's
full: let it stand till next Morning then
turn it Carefully least you Break it, so do
for three days, then lay it in Green Rushes
and Flannel, & it will be ready to eat in six
Days, if theweather is hot this Quantity
will make two Cheeses; straw fatts are best,

Pare large Sevil Oranges very thin Cut a peice
out where the stalk Grows, take out the seeds &
Juice, and save that comes out, then boil your
Oranges in a large Kettle of water, & shift
it, when it is very Bitter, with hot water, when
Tender take them out & dry them, then take to
Every Pound of Orange, a pound or Butter of
Double refine Sugar and to every pound, a
pint of water, make a Syrup & put in the
Oranges and boil them while well in the
Syrup, then take them out and Cover them, &
let them stand in that two or three days,
boil the meat that comes out of the Oranges
being Pick'd Clean, from the seeds & skins,
put in their weight in fine sugar, set it by
when boil'd, take as many John Apples as
will make Jelly for them, take as many pints
as pounds of Oranges or more, & to every pint
a pound of sugar, boil it, & heat in the
Oranges in a Little of the Syrup, then put
them into the Jelly & boil some time then
take them out & put them in pots or Glasses, with holes
upwards, & fill them with the meat & Cover them with
Jelly

Half boil the Tongues, blanch & slice
them, Season them with Savory spice
with Balls, Slic'd Lemon, & Butter, and
Close the pye, when tis bak'd take a
Pint of Gravy, sweetbreads, Pallats, &
Cocks Combs, tossed up & pour'd into the Pye

Truss & season your Pigeons with
Savory Spice, lard them with Bacon,
and stuff them with forc'd meat lay on
Lamb stones, Sweet breads, and Butter and
Close the pye, A Hare, Chicken, or Capon
Pye is made the same way

Bone a side or haunch of Venison cut it
Square, & season it with pepper & salt make
it up in your aforesaid Pasty past, a peck
of flower, for a Buck Pasty, & 3 Quarters
for a doe, 2 pounds of Beef suet at the Bottom of your
Buck pasty & 1 1/2 pound of Ditto at the Bottom
for a doe, A Lamb pasty is made on the doe

p.head: A Brown Fricasee of Chickens & Rabits

div.p:
Cut them in peices, fry them in Brown butter
then have ready hot, a pint of Gravy, a
Little Claret, white wine, & strong Broth, 2
Anchovies, 2 slic'd Pallats, a Faggot of sweet
herbs, savory Balls & spice, thicken it
with Brown Butter, & Garnish with Lemon

p.head: A white Fricasee of the same

div.p:
Cut them in peices, wash them from the
Blood, & fry them on a slow fire, then
put them in a Tossing pan, with a pint
of Strong Broth, season them & toss them
up, when Almost enough put to them
Mushrooms, Oysters, Anchovys, & a
pint of Cream, thicken it with a bit of
Butter roll'd in flower,

Boil the Vinegar let it stand till it is Cold,
take a few Barberrys, stamp them, and
Squeeze them, & put them into the
Vinegar, & put it into the Jarr of
Barberrys, & strew a Little sugar
Between them.,

Slit your Pigg down the Back, take out all
the Bones, wash out all the Blood in 3
or 4 waters, wipe it dry, & season it with
Savory Spice, thyme, parsly, & salt, roll
it in an Hand Collar, in a Cloth tie it Close
and Boil it, with the Bones in 3 pints of
water, an handful of salt, a quart of
Vinegar, a faggot of sweet herbs whole
spice, a penny worth of Ising Glass,
when Tender take it off, & when Cold keep it
in the same Pickle,

Scour your Large silver Eels with salt,
slit them down the Back, take out all the bone
wash & dry them, season them with savory
Spice, & herbs, then roll each in Collars in
a Little Cloth, tie them Close, & boil them
in water & salt, with the heads & bones,
And 1/2 a pint of Vinegar, a faggot of
Sweet herbs, when they are tender, take
them up, tie them Close again, strain
the Pickle and keep the Eels in it;

51
No.110
To Preserve Damsons
To every pound of Damsons a pound of sugar, take some of the Damsons & boil them in
Water, then take half a pint of that Liquor
To wet your sugar, put 1/2poundof sugar more
To Answer your Liquor, boil it, boil your
Sugar and scum it Clear, and when it is
Cold cut your Damsons in the side & put
them in, & let them boil softly, scum them
a Little, then set them by till next day.
then set them on again & let them boil a
Little Longer, shake them, & scum them, till
they look clear, then put them in pots &
Boil the syrup a Little more, and put it to them

No.111
A Seed Cake
Take 3poundof Butter, work it with your Hands, till
it's no thicker then cream, then put in the Yolks
of 24 Eggs beat up by degrees, take 3 pounds ofbutter
the whites & beat & work them inup
by degrees, take 3poundof flower, & 3 pounds of sugar
dryws & sifted & strewed in by degrees, & 3 ounces
of Carraway seeds, & a little sack cover the pan
with a thin past & Butter it, thatit may slip
out, you must keep it stirring till it's in the
Oven, which must be very hot.

Take 1poundof Bacon, fat & Lean together,
1 poundof Beef, 1 poundof Veal, 1 pound of Pork, 1 poundof Beef
Sweet, Cut them small & Chop them, take
a Small Handful of sage, pick of the Leaves
Chop it fine, with a few Sweet Herbs;
Season pretty High with peper & salt,
You must have a Large gut, & fill it; then
Set on a Sauce pan of water, when it
Boils put it in, & prick the gut for fear
of Bursting, Boil it softly an Hour, then
Lay it on Clean Straw to Dry.

Boil your Brockely tender saving a
Large Bunch for the Middle, & 6 or 8 Little
thick sprigs to stick round, take a Toast
Half an Inch thick, toast it Brown, as big
as you would have it for your Dish or
Butter plate, Butter some Eggs thus: take
six Eggs, more or Less as you have Occasion,
Beat them well, put them into a Sauce pan
with a good piece of Butter, a Little salt,
keep beating them with a Spoon till they are
thick enough, then pour them on the toast, set the Biggst
Bunch of Brockely in the middle , & the other Littlepiece
round & about, & grarnish the round with Little Sprig

p.note:
of Brockely, this is a pretty side
Dish, or Corner plate

div.p:
You must take 6 pound of Good pork, free from
Skin, Grisles, & fat, Cut it very small, &
Beat it in a Mortar till it is very fine; then
Shred 6 pounds of Beef sewet very fine & free from all
Skin, Shred it as fine as Possible; then take a
Good deal of Sage, wash it very Clean,
pick of the Leaves, & Shred it very fine,
Spread your meat on a Clean Dresser or
Table, then Shake the Sage all over, about
3 Large spoonfuls; Shred the thin Kind of
a Middling Lemmon very & throw over, with
as Many sweet Herbs, when shred fine, as
Will fill a Large spoon; grate two Nutmegs
Over, throw over two Tea spoonfulls of
Pepper, a Large Spoonful of salt, then throw
over the Sewet, & mix it all well together
put it down Clove in a pot; when you use
them, roll them up with as much Egg as
Will make them roll Smooth, make them the
Size of Sausage, & fry them in Butter or
Good Driping, be sure it be hot before you
put them in, & keep rolling them About, when
they are thorough hot & of a fine Brown,
they are Enough, you may Chop this meat
very fine, if you don't Like it beat, veal eats
Well done this Way or Veal & Pork together,

p.note: You may Clean Guts some & fill them

div.p:
You must get 1/2 poundof Millet Seed, & after it is
Washed & picked Clean, put to it 1/2 pound of Sugar
A whole Nutmeg grated, & 3 Quarts of Milk.
When you have mixed all well together,
Break in 1/2 pound of Butter; Butter your dish,
pour it in and Bake it,

(No 116)
To Preserve Cherries with the Leaves & Stalks Green
First dip the Stalks & Leaves in the Best
Vinegar Boiling Hot, stick the Sprig upright
in a Sieve till they are dry; in the mean
Time Boil some Double refined Sugar to a
Syrup, & dip the Cherries, Stalks, & Leaves
in the Syrup, & Just let them Scald; Lay
them on a Sieve, & Boil the Sugar to a Candy
Height, then dip the Cherries, Stalks, Leaves
and all, then Stick the Branches in
Sieves, & dry them as you dry other
sweet meats; they Look well by Candle
Light in a Dessert,

p.head: To Preserve Hair &make it Grow thick

div.p:
Take 1 Quart of white wine, put in one Handful
of Rosemary flowers, 1/2pound of Honey, Distil them
together then Add a 1/4 of a pint of Oil of Sweet
Almonds shake it well together putt a Little in a
cup warm it Blood warm rub it on your Head

Take half a pound of Rice, wash it Clean,
put it in a Sauce pan, with a Quart of
Milk, keep it Stirring till it is very thick;
Take great Care it Dont Burn; then turn it
into a pan, & grate some Nutmeg into it, & two
teaspoonfuls of Beaten Cinnamon, a Little
Lemon peel Shred fine, six Apples, par'd
& Chopped Small: Mix all together with the
Yolks of 3 Eggs, & Sweetened to your palate,
then tie it up Close in a Cloth; put it into
Boiling water, & be sure to keep it Boiling
al the Times, an Hour & a Quarter will Boil
it, Melt Butter & pour over it & throw some
fine Sugar all over it; A Little wine in the
Sauce will be a great Additionto it

p.head: To make a good Plum Cake

div.p:
4 1/2 pound of Currands 3pounds of Flower 2 poundsof
Butter 1 ounce of suet Spice 3/4 pounds of Sugar
12 Eggs Half the Whites 3 Hours
Bake it

Boil 1 ounce & 1/2 of Iseing .as., in Quart of
clear Spring water, till it comes to three Quarters
of a Pint, and boil in a bit of Lemon Peels,
just to give it flavour, but not to make it
Bitter, when it is Cold put n as much thick Cream
as will make it white, then put in a spoonful
of rose water, and a Spoonful of Orange flower
Water, squese in a very Little Lemon, three or four
spoonfuls of Sack a mountain wine, Sweeten it with
fine Sugar; if you like to have Some grean you
may Colour it with juice of Spinage

Cut your Beef into Steaks season it
with Pepper & Salt, then Bake it with
Butter, and when it is Quite Tender pour
the fat and Gravy off, and beat it with a
Little of the Butter, and put a little anchovy
into it but no Gravy, for that will make it not
keep then put it into the Pot you intend to
keep it in, and cover it with the Remainder of
the Butter, just set it into a Slow Oven after
you have put it into the Pot, you intend
Keeping it in before you cover it with Butter

p.head: To Salt a Buttock of Beef like Ham

div.p:
Take 2 ouncesof Salt Peater 1/2 pound of Coarse
Sugar, as much common Salt as you
Use for a Buttock of Beef, Let it lay
a Month, then Sow it very tithe in a
Cloth Boile it 10 Hours put in the
water Cold, when you Boile it; and when
Tender take it out & Ty a Cloath over the
other Tithe and put it upon a Dish with a
Board upon it and waite to press it Down
Close and the next Day Take all the
Clothes off and then take the Loose skin
from it
To Make Catchup of Walnuts

Take the Walnuts when they are fit for
Pickeling pound then in a Mortar, then Strain
the Juce, through a flannell Bag put to every
Quart of Juce a pint Vinegar Let it Stand
four Days then Boile it over a Slow fire to Half
th Quantity Scum it a Little put in some

57
Shallotts some spice the peels of three Civil
Oranges Pared thin then Let it stand 3 Weeks or
a Month Cover'd very Close then Boyle it after
Bottlee it you may put in Anchovys & Salt if
you Please

To make Leach or Ffeing Glass Plumery
(N.124) Take one ounce of Ffeing Glass shave it thin
and steep it in about a Quarter of a Pint of water
with a Blade of Mace; and Little bit of Lemon
Peal for about 16 Hours, then put it into a
scillett or saucepan, with a Quart of New Milk
and boil it till its all Desolved stirring it all
the Time till its all Desolved then strain it
through a Cloath into Pots; before you strain
it out into an Earthen pan stir it till the Heat
is a Little off then put about two or three
Spoonfuls of Brandy into it and a Littlee sugar

The Calves Head must be Sealded and not
Skined, Cut it in Slices about as Large as a
Crown Piece Take also two Neat Feet Boiled
whole, and then Cut in Pieces stew them in good
Veal Broth put to them an Onion a Faggot of
Sweet Herbs half a Pint of Madeira; or Common
White Wine that is not sweet and Tea Spoonful of
Red pepper Keep them Boiling gently till they are
quite Tender Serve them up; with forced Meat
Balls and yolks of Eggs boiled Hard: The Broth
may be made of the Neck and Bones of the Head:
it should be well Seasoned with Pepper Onions
and Herbs and a Little Salt then strain it of quite
Clear from Fat; about three Pints of Broth will be
Sufficint for the Whole Head: the Bones & Coarse
Peices of the Neck will make the quantity
Burn a Little Butter not to Brown Chiann Pepper
and Madeira made Hot put to the Sauce

Shred a pound of the Inside of a Surline of Beef
1 pound 3/4 of Beef Suet 5 pippens a Gratted Lemon
peele season it with 1 ounce of sweet Spices 1/2 pound of Sugar
2 pounds of Currands 1/2 a Pint of Sack a Little orange
flower water the juice of three Lemmons a 1/4 of a pound
of Cittron Lemon and Orange peele mix these together
and fill your pyes put a Tea Spoonful of Red Wine
into Each pye

Take 1 douzen of green pippins or Codlings, pared
& Quarterd, Slice them into a pint of Water
& put in 3 or 4 of the worst Apricots Sliced &
The pairings of the rest, Boil it as fast as you
can tell half is Boiled away Then take to this Liquor
a pound of Apricots pared & Stoned, a pound & half of Lump
Suger put the Liquer in the Suger, & when it is
Boild up & is scum'd put in You Apricots when
they look clear they are Enough; Run the Liquor
thro' a Jelly Bag, before you put your Suger in;

128
To make a Carrot Puding the best way

Take half a pound of Grated white Bread & half
a pound of Carrot Grated & 6 ounces of New Butter
& six Eggs & four Whites & as much Ginger as you
think fit & a Spoonful or two of Orange Flower,
or Rose Water, & a little cream, Mix all together
& pat it in a Dish Butterd or a putt past under it
About 1 hour Bakes it ; Take care it does not Scorch.

To every Ham, one ounce of salt petre
Rub it all over, let them lay 24 Hours, then put
2 quarts Stale Beer in a Sauce pan, half a pound
of Bay Salt Half a pound of Common salt Boil
them all together, pour it Boiling Hot on the Hams,
Rub & & turn them Every Day for a fortnight
make them 2 Days over Saw Dust, then dry
them in the Chimney: NotaBene you must Boil
half a pound of Coarse Sugar in the Liquor
If the Ham is large let it lye 3 weeks in it:

Take a Gallon of New Milk & warm it:
& put in it a Cupfull of Rennet You must
set the Night before a bit of Rennet bag,
as big as a Crown peice in a Capfull
of Water & the next day put the Water
to Your New Warm Milk & when the Curd
is come put it in a Cheese Cloth, & Wave
it back & forwards till the whey is out of it
then take the Same Weight of new butter,
as Your Curd, & press it thro' a Seive
then put in 8 Eggs leaving out 4 Whites,
currants & lumpt sugar & Spices to Your
taste put them in Puff paste & bake them
in Pans:

Take Your Wallnuts, put them in to Cold Water,
set it over the fire till the Water is very Hot,
but not to Boil, let them Stand in the Water a
quarter of an Hour, them take them out of that Water
& put them in to Cold Water with a large Handfull
of Salt, change the Water every Day for 10 or 12 Days
Rub of the out Side Skin when dry put Your
pickle to them Boiling Hot put in to Your pickle
Garlick Shallots, Mustard seed, Horse Radisk &
Whole Pepper:

To half a pound of Flour, take 6 ounces of Butter
1 ounce or rather less of Loaf sugar beat, & sifted
rub them all together till the butter is quite small
& wet it very stiff with Boiling Water, it eats the Crisper

quarter of a pound of Rice, quarter of a pound of Loaf sugar
both sifted, 4 Eggs, half the Whites well Mix'd together
You may add a few Almonds if you please
the Juice of half a Lemmon & the peal:

p.head: To Make Mead the best way

div.p:
Take 4 pund of Hony to 1 gallon of Apple juice
& boil it the same as Mead,

p.head: To make a bake'd Apple pudden

div.p:
Take 3 quarters of a pound of sharn Apple Sead E'm
& pulp them, take Eight Eggs half the whites half a Pound sugar
sugar the juice of one Lemon & peal grate'd
put to it half a pound of Butter Melted & a
sheet of puff past under it ,

Take the thin flank clear of the inside skin
take out all the gristles, take a quarter of a pound
of salt peter beat it fine, & mix it with as
much common salt as will sack it very Well
let it lye a fortnight turning it Every Day, &
Rubing it very well, then take it out of the Brine
& wash it very well & dry it with a Cloath,
Take a good Handfull of parsly, some sage & Thyme
chop altogether very small Nutmeg grated
& Mix,d together & strew it over the Inside of
the Beef, then Role it up very hard & Tye it
with Tape all over, put in a Pot Cover it with Water
with some whole pepper; Tye it down close & bake it with Houshold Bread

Take half a Pound of Almonds Blanch'd, & beaten small
with Rose Water, half of pound of sugar beaten fine
3/4 of a Pound of Butter Melted, & almost Cold again,
Eight Yolks of Eggs well beat, the peal of a large
sivil Orange boild till it is very Tender & the bitter
almost out, beat it in a morter till its Tender,
then mix all these together & beat it well,
& put it in a Crust:

Take 2 pound of flour, one pound butter rubed in
very fine, 12 Eggs leave out 6 whites, 11 Spoonfuls
of Cream & Eleven Spoonfuls of Yeast, mix these
together very well, then beat it up with your Hand,
Let it before the fire to Rise for a quarter of an Hour
then strew Carraway seeds, drop them on Tin sheets
set them in with white bread, a quarter of an hour bake

To Butter Quinces
Make four Water Boil, & put in the Quinces,
& keep them turn'd till they are soft & then take
them out & peal them as quick as you can,
mash them, & put to them Butter & Sugar:

Take the Buds of Damask Roses, & pull them
out of the green, & throw away all the seeds & green
green, & if there is any of the Buds thick at
the Bottom of the Rose cut it of, & put none of
it in, then take Cloves, & Salt Petre & beat em'
fine & put in your Pot, or Glass, some of it
at the bottom, & then a layer of Roses, &
then a Layer of the cloves & salt Petre
till your Pot is quite full, tye it down for a
month before you open it:

p.head: To make the British Herb Tobacco

div.p:
Take Colts foot leaves, & wood Brittany flowers
Eye bright, & Time, Sweet Marjorum, Rosemary
& Lavender, put as much in weight of the Colts foot
as you do of all the rest:

To 3 pounds of grapes when pick'd, put one pound & half
of six peny Sugar, & one Quart of Water
Stamp the Grapes, & strain the juice from them
then put the Husks in to the Water, & let them
Stand 24 Hours, then Strain them of as dry as
You can, put that Liquor to the Juice of the Grapes,
you must put in some of the Sugar to the
juice of the grapes when they are first straind of,
& the remainder when the whole is mixe'd, you must
let it stand one year in the Vessel, & then Bottle it:

3 quarters of a pound of Calves feet, take out the brown
& Fat, & chop it very Fine, the same quantity
of suet, & the same of Currents, a little Sugar,
a little Salt, A Spoonfull of Brandy, Sack, & orange
flower, or Rose Water, 6 Eggs half the Whites
a little Mace & Nutmeg; a very little grated Potead
Boil this Quantity 5 Hours: & pour over it
Butter Wine & Sugar:

Take Eleven new laid Eggs, their weight in Loaf sugar
finely beaten & sifted, & the weight of 7 in fine flour
well dry'd before the fire, with the rind of a Lemon
grated in to it; then break your Eggs, the
yolks into one pan, the whites in to another,
which must be whisk'd with a Strong Hand, Till
never leasing till its as stiff as snow, the Yolks
must be beat with a wooden pudding stirrer,
& then put the sugar to them & keep them beating
till the whites of the Eggs are ready; then put
in to the Yolks & sugar, & beat it well Together;
Then put in your flour by Degrees, & beat it well in,
Butter your Tins which must be but half full,
Your oven must be quick but not Scorching,
a very little time bakes them, Dust a little Sugar
over them when you put them in to the oven; as Ices them

Boil half a pound of Hartshorn shaveings in 3
pints of Water, till it comes to a pint, put in with
it a bit of Iseinglass,strain it through a thin Cloth,
when it is cold put it in a Saucepan again,
with a quarter of a pint of very thick cream,
let it be Hot again but not Boil, put in a
little Wine but not too much, Sugar to your Tast
dip your Cup in Water as you put it in
& dip them in warmwater when you turn them out

One ounce of Hartshorn shavings, four ounces of Isinglass,
two ounces of Iringo Root, three Vipers dry'd,
a pint of Snails, Boyl all in three quarts of Water till it
comes to a T...o, take a Spoonfull warmed with a
spoonfull of white Whine as often as you like, the oftener
the better, with a little Lemon & sugar to make it palatable,
It may be taken at first waking in the morning, with a little
milk, but afterwards with Wine:

Take two Spoonfuls of Cream, and one of Honey in a
Morning fasting:

Eight Eggs all the whites, 1 pound sugar,
3/4 of a pound of flower, a little white wine
a little mace & nutmeg, bear altogether for
an Hour, Bake'd in a Quick Oven

Two Gallons of water to one Gallon of Juice
3 pound of sugar to a gallon, strain it, put it in
the Cask, & when you think it has work'd enough
put in a Quart of Brandy to 7 Gallons; rather less
sugar will do if you make but a small Cask

A pound & a half of sugar wet with a little
juice of Red Currants make it boil, & then add
2 pound of Gooseberrys to the Liquor, & boil
them Enough to keep:

p.head: To make a good side Dish

div.p:
Take some large Cucumbers & scoop out all
the seeds, & fill them up with a good force meat
made with Veal, & fry them, & stew them in
a Strong Gravy, & serve them up in it
NotaBene they must be pared after they are
scooped, before you put the force meat in it:

Take Lavender, & St Johns wort, Rosemary
Lavender cotton, Penyroyal, Caomile, Rue
Balm, adderstongue, Featherfue, Blood wort
wormwood, Red sage, Chouch grass, Chariz or
Jacobs ladder, marsh mallows, Dwarf Elder
Solomons seal, of each one Handfull,
Chop them small & put them in to 2 quarts
of the best Oil, in a glass or stone jar,
Let them stand 15 Days in the Sun
String it often, strain it out & put in
the same Quantity of Herbs, as before, Leting it
stand 15 Days longer then strain the
Herbs out & boil it in a Pipkin over a
Clear Fire, then take it of, let it stand
till the next day, & pour of the clear in
Bottles:

NotaBene 2 Handfulls of addersspears, must be
put in the first time
& 1 handfull of water Bittany each time:

p.head: To make a salve from the Herbs of the oil Charity

div.p:
To the Herbs that are Straind out, take half a pint
of Linseed Oil & put to them, & strain the herbs, from
the Linseed oil, & put to it the settleings of the first herbs
with a Quarter of a Pound of Red Led, 2 ounces of
Turpintine, 2 ounces of Rosin, 4 ounces of Bees wax
set it on a gentle fire stiring it till all disolved
then boil it till it comes to a salve. It is good for
Bruises or wounds, or a sore breast a good
scar cloth for pains or Aches, It must be boild
some hours, till it looks black, then Pour it into
water make it in roles, puting a peice of bladder
on it.

Take 2 ounces of pearl Barly, 2 of Hartshorn shavings 2 of Eringe
root candid, 20 snails in shells; Boil them in 3 pints
of water till it comes to a Quart strain it out
and take 2 spoonfuls every morning fasting, in 4
spoonfuls of new milk warm, These Ingredients
must be fresh made in 3 or 4 Days

2 ounces of Burnt Hartshorn,
to 2 Quarts of Water & Boil it till
the third part is Boild away then Dip
in a peice of old Damask or Diaper
& boil it in it a Quarter of an Hour
then take it out, & Drain, & let it dry
The Liquor that is left may be Bottled
up for use.

To two ounces of Brazil, put a small peice
of Allum, boil it for half an Hour

A quarter of a Pound of Logwood, & a
little Allum, boild for half an Hour

Mix Logwood & verdigrease,
Boil it half an Hour

To every Quart of Rum 8 or 9 Oranges,
and half a pound of good Loaf Sugar
disolve the Sugar in the Juice, before the Rum
is put to it,put it into a Cork, shaking
it every day or two several times when
settled & fine, draw it of and Bottle it for use

Pare the rinds of 12 Lemons very thin
squeese out the juice & pulp but do not pat
in the seeds nor white, steep all this in
7 pints of Common Brandy for 4 Days
Take six Pints of water & a Pound & half
of fine sugar, boil it & scum it till clear
when Gold put it to the afore said ingredeints
The Night before you put it through your Jelly
bag put in a Quart of boiling milk

Par boil it, cut it in peices, beat a little
mace, Nutmeg, Alspice, cloves & a very little
bagon Pepper, salt, & Lemon Peel Grated
sweet Marjorum & Thyme; season the Head
with it, lay it in a Dish, put in a little
gravy, beat the Brains with a spoonful
of white wine & pour them over it,
shake in a little Flour & pour in a
little Hot Water, before it is Baked Butter
a Paper & lay on it boil hard Eggs &
put in it, & Garnish the Dish with
Lemon Barberrys

2 ouncesof Bottle Gunpowder
1 ounces of brown mustard seed bruised
1 ounce of Bark

To be put in a Quart of Mountain Wine
frequently shook for 24 Hours then it
will be fit for use, Then it will be fit
for use, and a Wine glass full to be taken
three times a Day

Take Three Spoonfuls of Sweet Oil
Six Spoonfuls of Peppermint Water
a little Fine Sugar, a few drops
of Hartshorn, shake it well together
& take a Table spoonful now & then:

Dissolve 2 ounces of corrosive Sablimate
in one Quart of Spirits of wine
to be used with a Brush

one Ounce of Bark Chips, put into
3 Pints of Water & boil till its reduced to
a Quart, Let it stand constantly by the
Fire, A Tea Cup full must be taken
at Eleven & four in the Afternoon
just warm with a Tea Spoonful of
Lavender Drops or a little small
Pepper Mint Water; It must be taken
Constantly till the Fever is quite removed

Take Lime, a little Whiting & Yellow oaker to give
the Colour, a Quart of oil to a Pail Full, the whole
mix'd with vizYou may mix a small quantity
of all these videlicet, 2 Quarts, then apply some of it
to a bit of an ild Wall, when the colour is perfectly
dry, you may remark whether it pleases, or not
as you may mix more or less Oaker to give it
the exact Hue, you would wish to have it
& so of the rest of the Articles the quantitys
of each being attended to, mix them altogether
in the same proportion in a Vesel Sufficent
to contain a large quantity, & so till you have
Compleated the whole, it must be frequently stird
as it is Brushing on the work, if the Bricks
are Mossy, it should be rubed off, before you
begin the work.

2 Handfulls of Hone radish leaves, in two
gallons of soft water with one ounce of Allum
let it lye all night in the Dye the next Day
wash it out in cool soap & water
it may then be Galenderd

Take a Pint of water, a Quarter of a pound
of Butter, a little salt, put it in a Stewpan
& let it boil, till the Butter is melted,
take a pint of flouer, & put in to the Stewpan
stiring it as fast as you can, with a wooden
spoon & break all the nobs till tis almost
cold, then break in 4 Eggs & stir it well
fry them brown with Lard put the batter in
with a Tea Spoon in small bits to fry
The same Batter makes very good fritters
made a little thiner

Boil the head almost Enough & when cold
take one half of it, with the Tongue, cut it
in Slices, clear from the bone & put it
in to a pan with some strong broath
about 2 spoonfuls of White Wine, a bunch
of sweet Herbs 2 or 3 shallots, a Nutmeg in
Quarters, a little whole pepper, & let them
stew over a Slow fire till it is Enough
then put in 1 large Anchovy the Yolks of
2 Eggs well beat thicken it up with a
peice of Butter Then have ready, some
slices of thin Bacon Fried, some force meat
Balls the Brains first boild then dipt in Batter
& fry in little cakes, The other half of the Head
broild with crums of Bread strewd over it
being first washed over with the Yolks of Eggs
pour the Hash in the Dish, lay the broild head
upon it, & garnish it with the Brains
Balls, & Lemon

p.head: For the Gravel by Dr Ratcliffe

div.p:
Take one ounce of Marsh Mallow roots
2 ounces of Pearl barley; put them into
3 pints of Water, & boil it to a quart
strain it into a bowl upon an ounce
of Gum Arabic, & Sweeten it to the Taste
with Honey. Aglass to be talen Morning &
Evening.

p.head: Mock Asses Milk, Mr Hardwick Apothecary

div.p:
Take Comforey Root one Ounce; sage & Rice
each half an Ounce, Isinglass Quarter of an Ounce
Boil these Ingredients in three pints of Water
till it comes to a Quart & keep the Liquor for
use, Take of the above Liquor & Milk Equal
parts, & to be drank at pleasure

A pint of skim milk, put in the third part of
a pound of Raisins of the sun Stoned, & cut small,
Boil it & as the curd rises Squeeze in half a
Seville orange when the curd is risen, pour it
through a sive, & set it by for your Breakfast
next Morning drink it Cold in Summer & warm
in winter, it will parse the Blood more than
anything, I have used in these four years & it
has cured me of the Most Violent Scurvey
that ever man was affected with, & it is
the pleasantest Breakfast I ever had

This was taken from Lord Chesterfeilds
own hand writing

Half a pound of Bread gratted, Ditto Suet
Ditto Apples Chopped fine, Ditto of Currants
a Quarter of a pound of Sugar, Four Eggs,
a little Lemon peel, half a glass of Brandy,
: To be boild 3 Hours;

Take one Bushel of Elderberrys when pick'd
to nine Gallons of Water let them soak 4 Days
then boil it well, & strain of the Berrys
to the clear Liwuor, put 38 pound of Common
lump sugar, 2 oz of Bruised Ginger 1 ounce of
all spice half an ounce of Cloves, the same of Mace
to be boild again one Hour, 1 Gallon of water
to be added to allow for boiling away
then to be workd in a Tub; when put inthe
Barrel add 1 Bottle of Brandy; not to be
stopd down under two or three Days
To be Bottled of when fine

Rub the mushrooms with a bit off Cannel
& salt & put them in Salt & Water, then
scald them in salt & Water when done dry
them in a Cloath well, then put them in
some common Vinegar, boiling let them stand
all night then drain them well & put them in
doubled Distilld Vinegar, with a little white
pepper & Mace, Tie them over with a Bladder

Hartshorn shaveings, Pearl Barly & sage each 2 ounces
1 ounce of Candid Erings Root a little Lemon peal
boild in 2 Quarts of Water, till it comes to 3 Pints
strain it off, about half a pint should be takin
the first thing in the Morning if stomach will bear it
in the middle of the Day & the last thing at Night
adding a Spoonful of White Wine, each time
or not, as its liked best:

Take a Dram of Saffron
A Dram of Cochineal 2 Ounces of White
Sugar candy put it in a quart of the best
Brandy when it has infus'd 24 hours
it is fit for use take half a gill of it
and put it in a half pint mugg and take
it to a Cow and milk it full Take it in
a morning fasting let the Patient walk after

To a Peek of Sprats, take 2 pound of common Salt,
2 quarter of a pound of Baye Salt, Quarter pound Salt Petre
2 ounces of Prunella Salt & a small quantity
of Cochineal, Pound all in a Mortar,
put them in to a stone jar, a row of Sparts
then a layer of your Compound, &
and so on alternately to the Top
Press them hard down cover them close
let them stand for Six months, & they
will be fit for use Take particular care
that Your Sprats be very fresh, & do not
wash or Wipe them, but take them
just as they come out of the water:

Rub the mushroons with a bit of Flannel & Salt
& put them in salt & Water, then Scald them in
Salt & Water, when done dry them in a Cloath,
then put them in some common Vinegar Boiling
let them stand all night then drain 'em well
and put them in double distild Vinegar
with a little white pepper, & mace, Tye them
over with a Bladder

Two Pounds of Flower, half a pound Buttter,
half a pound of Sugar, two large Spoonfuls of Yeast
two Eggs, & an ounce of Carraaway Seeds,
Melt the Butter in a Sauce Pan by itself,
& pour it of from the settlement at bottom
wet the Cake with Warm Milk:

p.head: To make a Baked Plumb Pudding

div.p:
one Pound Raisins, 1 pounpickled Pork boild
Chopd fine, pour the pork & the water its boild in,
in to a pan & let it stand till cold. then strain
the Fat off, & mix the Fat & the Pork with
1 pound 3/4 Flour wet with Milk, add a little salt,
1 or 2 Eggs, tho may be made without

A Common Board, coverd with thick buff Leather,
or which is put Emery one part, Crocus Marsh's 3 part
in very fine powder, mixd in to a Thick paste
with a little Lard, or sweet oil spread or the Leather
the thickness of a shilling gives a superior
polish & Edge to Knives & does not wear
the Knives, a gnarlerdo much, as Brick dust
or a Board

1 ounce of Brown Mustard Seed, boild in
12 quart of Water a full half Hour
put to it 1 pint of Milk, when it turns
Strain it off begin with drinking
or going to Bed, a large Coffee cup full
increase it, till it comes to half a pint
Continue it a Fortnight

p.supplied:
A number of blank pages follow
and have not been photographed.
